setup_query_code: any(input$data_collection_method == "Survey Sample" & (input$strata_variables %in% colnames(global_values$selected_data) | input$strata_variables == "") & any(sapply(input$strata_variables, function(var) anyNA(global_values$selected_data[[var]]))))

setup_query_code: all(input$data_collection_method == "Survey Sample" & (input$population_size_variables %in% colnames(global_values$selected_data) | input$population_size_variables == "" & input$strata_variables %in% colnames(global_values$selected_data) | input$strata_variables == "") & max(sapply(input$strata_variables, function(var) { length(unique(global_values$selected_data[[var]])) })) < nrow(as.data.frame(table(global_values$selected_data[,c(input$population_size_variables, input$strata_variables)]))[as.data.frame(table(global_values$selected_data[,c(input$population_size_variables, input$strata_variables)]))$Freq != 0,]))
error_message: The population size variable [$population_size_variables] should correspond to the stratification variable [$strata_variables], with each category of [$strata_variables] having only one unique value for [$population_size_variables]. Select a different variable or make the necessary changes in your dataset. You will need to re-import the dataset into the application before proceeding to analysis.
